title: Middle East crisis live: Israel issues evacuation order for Yemen ports
snippets:
People told to flee from three ports after Israeli military says it intercepted a missile launched from Yemen

  • Israel hits hospitals in deadly strikes

In another portion of an interview on BBC radio in the UK, Israeli government spokesperson David Mencer sought to put some distance between Benjamin Netanyahu’s policy on Gaza and statements made by ministers in his coalition government.

It was put to Mencer that defense minister Israel Katz has previously said a food blockade on Gaza was the main lever to use against Hamas, while finance minister Bezalel Smotrich had said Gaza would be “entirely destroyed.”

I’m speaking on behalf of the prime minister. We are a broad government. There are many members of the government, but the prime minister, as the name suggests, it is led by Benjamin Netanyahu. He sets policy.

And I can share with you that Israel faces a moral paradox right now. It’s been created by Hamas. We have an opportunity to strike every military target, but when we do, we get condemned, you know, or we don’t strike them, and we reward the use of human shields.

Now look this Witkoff proposal is a phased deal. It means that Hamas must release hostages.

But the reason why we have put this military threat, and the reason why our hostage was released over the last couple of days was because we put this military threat on to Hamas now.

Continue reading...
titles: Middle East crisis live: Israel issues evacuation order for Yemen ports
summary: After intercepting a missile from Yemen, Israel directed evacuations from three ports and conducted deadly strikes on hospitals in Gaza. Israeli spokesperson David Mencer clarified Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's stance on Gaza, contrasting it with other ministers' more aggressive policies. Mencer outlined Israel's dilemma in targeting military objectives without international condemnation and mentioned a phased proposal requiring Hamas to release hostages, implying recent military threats led to a hostage's release.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful context about the ongoing crisis in the Middle East, including Israel's response to a missile attack from Yemen and its strategy for dealing with Hamas. However, it does not report on any solutions or attempts to resolve the conflict, nor does it fully explain the causes or potential impacts of the situation.

title: China criticises UK-US trade deal; Aviva’s £3.7bn acquisition of Direct Line faces competition probe – business live
snippets:
Beijing says it is a ‘basic principle’ that bilateral agreements should not target other nations

Here’s a bit more detail on Burberry’s sweeping job cuts.

Joshua Schulman, the chief executive of Burberry, said the majority of the 1,700 cuts would be at the group’s head offices around the world – led by London – but jobs would also go by reorganising staff rotas in stores and dropping one shift at its factory in Castleford.

For a long time we have had over capacity at that facility and that’s simply not sustainable at this point. We are making this change to safeguard our UK manufacturing and will be making a significant investment in renovating the factory [later this financial year].

The environment was challenging. And the second half of the year will also remain demanding for the overall economy in Europe. Our integrated and diversified business model with its activities in Europe and increasingly also outside Europe, proved its worth again in the second quarter.

We are offering more and more products in more destinations for existing and new customers… More individuality, flexible options and the proven security of package holidays are the strengths of dynamically sourced travel offerings.

Continue reading...
titles: China criticises UK-US trade deal; Aviva’s £3.7bn acquisition of Direct Line faces competition probe – business live
summary: Beijing has criticized bilateral agreements that target other nations, emphasizing it as a fundamental principle. In related news, Burberry's CEO, Joshua Schulman, announced the company is cutting 1,700 jobs globally, including at its London head offices and Castleford factory, to address overcapacity and ensure the sustainability of its UK manufacturing. The company plans significant investment in the Castleford factory renovation later in the financial year. This decision comes amid a challenging economic environment in Europe, with Burberry aiming to adapt by offering more products and flex
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful information about international trade relations and business decisions, helping readers understand the current economic climate and the strategies companies like Burberry are using to adapt. However, it doesn't highlight any solutions or progress towards solving the issues mentioned.

title: Australian workers claw back hit to living standards as wages outpace inflation
snippets:
The 1% climb in real pay was the fastest in five years, and twice the five-year average leading into the pandemic

  • Australia news live: latest politics and federal election updates
  • Full federal election results: live Australian Senate seat count
  • See our full coverage of the Australian election

Australian workers are clawing back the hit to their living standards from the high cost of living, as wages handily outpaced inflation in the year to March.

Hourly rates of pay climbed by 3.4% through the 12-month period, versus a 2.4% rise in prices, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

Continue reading...

Australian workers are clawing back the hit to their living standards from the high cost of living, as wages handily outpaced inflation in the year to March.

titles: Australian workers claw back hit to living standards as wages outpace inflation
Australian workers claw back hit to living standards as wages outpace inflation
summary: In Australia, real pay increased by 1% in the year to March, marking the fastest growth in five years and doubling the average of the previous five years before the pandemic. This rise in wages, at 3.4%, outstripped inflation, which stood at 2.4%, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. This development indicates that Australian workers are making progress in recovering from the impact of high living costs.
constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive as it reports on a positive trend in the Australian economy, providing readers with a deeper understanding of the current state of wages and inflation in the country. It also indicates progress in terms of workers' living standards improving.

titles: Did an Exploding Magnetar Forge the Gold in Your Wedding Ring?

This finding, supported by new evidence from a historic flare along with past observations, proposes that magnetars could have a larger impact on galactic chemistry, and potentially on planet and life formation, than previously understood.

title: Lightning-Fast Alchemy: CERN Just Turned Lead Into Gold – Then Watched It Vanish
snippets: An experiment has measured gold formation from lead nuclei during near-miss collisions in the Large Hadron Collider. These high-speed interactions trigger electromagnetic processes that occasionally eject three protons, yielding gold atoms. Billions are made, but only for a split second. Lead to Gold: A Modern Alchemical Feat at CERN In a newly published study in [...]
titles: Lightning-Fast Alchemy: CERN Just Turned Lead Into Gold – Then Watched It Vanish
summary: CERN scientists have successfully transformed lead into gold in an experiment at the Large Hadron Collider by causing near-miss collisions of lead nuclei. These collisions initiate electromagnetic processes that can eject three protons from a lead nucleus, resulting in the formation of gold atoms. However, the gold atoms exist only momentarily, disappearing after a split second. This modern alchemy, while demonstrating the theoretical possibility of transforming lead into gold, does not yield stable or lasting gold.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful information about an experiment at CERN, contributing to a deeper understanding of nuclear physics. However, it doesn't offer actionable insights or report on any practical applications of this knowledge. It also doesn't increase clarity around systems, causes, trends, or impacts that matter.

constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive because it provides readers with a deeper understanding of chimpanzee behavior and the potential origins of medicinal use in early humans. title: Young Stars Feed on Chaos to Build Planets
snippets: A new study flips our view of planet formation by showing that young stars can absorb surrounding material, extending the life and size of their disks. This process, Bondi-Hoyle accretion, solves long-standing mysteries and could influence where habitable planets can form. Environment’s Role in Planet Formation Uncovered A surprising new study is turning our understanding [...]
titles: Young Stars Feed on Chaos to Build Planets
summary: A recent study has revealed that young stars can extend the lifespan and size of their disks by absorbing surrounding material through a process known as Bondi-Hoyle accretion. This discovery challenges previous understandings of planet formation and suggests that the environment plays a significant role in determining where habitable planets might emerge. The findings could help solve longstanding mysteries in the field of astronomy.
constructiveness_reason: This story is highly constructive as it provides useful insights into a new understanding of planet formation. It reports on an innovative study that challenges previous theories, indicating progress in the field of astronomy. The story also increases awareness about the factors that could determine where habitable planets might emerge.
